1. The text discusses the processes of selection, random genetic drift, and mutations as the underlying mechanisms of Darwinian evolution. It explains how population geneticists have analyzed these processes in the simplest setting of two genotypes. The fitness of a genotype represents the selection pressure for the individuals and defines the expected number of offspring an individual will produce.
2. The text also discusses frequency-dependent selection, where an individual's fitness not only depends on its genotype but also on its interactions with other individuals and the frequency of the different genotypes in the population. This type of selection had been studied early on by Crow and Kimura but has only recently received more attention. The text explains how individuals' interactions are represented by interaction matrices from game theory, leading to a frequency dependence where the fitness depends directly on the interaction parameters in a linear way.
3. The text highlights the impact of nonlinear frequency dependence on coevolutionary dynamics, which may induce new stable configurations of the evolutionary dynamics. It also discusses the impact of asymmetric mutation probabilities on the dynamics, which was neglected in most models until now.
4. The text is based on the Moran process in a non-spatial environment, which is a well-established model to study evolutionary dynamics. The Moran process is a stochastic birth-death process that keeps the population size constant. In a two-genotype model, the system becomes effectively one-dimensional, and the dynamics may be described by a one-dimensional Markov chain with transition rates defined by the Moran process. The article derives the stationary probability distribution of the system dynamics via its Fokker-Planck equation.

The thin-interface limit is used to analyze the equations of the phase-field model under the assumption that the interface thickness is much smaller than any other physical length scale, yielding effective boundary conditions that contain all effects of the finite interface thickness up to the order of the expansions.

8. Several extensions of the antitrapping current have been put forward to generalize the approach to the case of finite diffusivity in the solid, and simulations show that the approach works well for the instability of a steady-state planar interface and for free dendritic growth.

1. Topological insulators (TIs) are a class of materials with non-trivial topological invariants and robust surface metallic states, which are realized in systems with strong spin-orbit interaction.
2. All known TIs contain heavy or rare metal elements, which poses constraints on the search for topological materials. However, it has been proposed that ubiquitous Coulomb repulsions among electrons can generate effective spin-orbit couplings and lead to a topologically non-trivial phase.
3. An extended Hubbard model on the honeycomb lattice can generate an effective spin-orbit interaction from a spontaneous symmetry breaking at the Hartree-Fock mean-field level, leading to a topological Mott insulator (TMI) phase.
4. The TMI phase is unusual because an emergent spin-orbit interaction appears from the electronic mutual Coulomb interaction, and it shows an unconventional quantum criticality that depends on the electron band dispersion near the Fermi point.
5. However, realizing the proposed TMI phase in real materials has not been achieved, and it is not clear whether the TMIs become stable against competitions with other orders and quantum fluctuations.
6. Examining charge fluctuations with finite momentum over entire Brillouin zones is an alternative way to clarify the competitions among TMIs and charge density waves (CDWs), as studied by employing functional renormalization group methods.
7. The most plausible symmetry breaking competing with TMIs is a first-order quantum phase transition, and quantum many-body fluctuations beyond the mean-field approximation severely affect the stability of the TMI.
8. The stability of the TMI and estimation of the critical value of interaction on the honeycomb lattice have been considered by mean-field calculations, but a reliable limit where the TMI becomes stable is for infinitesimally small relevant Coulomb repulsions, where the quadratic band crossing with vanishing Fermi velocities causes the leading instability toward the TMI.

</summary>

This model, a phenomenological extension of the standard model of semiflexible polymers, has been successful in describing a wide range of rheological data for polymer solutions and living cells over many decades with a minimum of parameters.

They propose a theoretical framework for a polymer-based description of the inelastic nonlinear mechanical behavior of sticky biopolymer networks.

In this paper, the authors study planar brushes of flexible, semiflexible, and rodlike diblock polyampholytes using MD simulations in a wide range of grafting density.

1. Chimera states, which are the coexistence of coherent and incoherent oscillations in a network of identical phase oscillators, have been observed in various models such as Kuramoto phase oscillators, periodic and chaotic maps, Stuart-Landau oscillators, and coupled chemical oscillators. These states were first discovered in populations of coupled chemical oscillators and optical coupled-map lattices, and later in mechanical experiments involving two subpopulations of identical metronomes. In neuroscience, chimera states are believed to explain the phenomenon of unihemispheric sleep observed in many birds and dolphins. A new study has identified various single and multi-chimera states in networks of non-locally coupled neurons represented by Hindmarsh-Rose oscillators.
2. The Hindmarsh-Rose model is a 2-dimensional simplification of the physiologically realistic Hodgkin-Huxley model and is computationally simpler to handle. However, it fails to reproduce several important dynamical behaviors shown by real neurons, such as rapid firing or regular and chaotic bursting. By replacing the Fhn model with the Hindmarsh-Rose (HR) model, which can reproduce these behaviors, the study identifies parameter values for which chimeras appear in this setting and notes the variety of oscillating patterns possible due to the bistability features of the 2d model. The study also discovers chimera-like patterns in the more natural setting where only the membrane potential variables are coupled. In the more realistic 3d-HR model, the system exhibits bursting modes, and chimera states are discovered when coupling is allowed only among the first (membrane potential) variables and spiking occurs within sufficiently long bursting intervals.

1. Kauffman networks are disordered dynamical systems used as a model for genetic regulatory systems. They were studied as an analogy to disordered systems in statistical mechanics, such as the mean field spin glass. A dynamical phase transition was found and studied in the framework of mean field theory. In this paper, the authors study the structural properties of the networks that determine their attractors, specifically focusing on the relevant elements and their probability distribution. The relevant elements are subdivided into asymptotically non-communicating, independent modules, which was suggested by Kauffman and used to study analytically the attractors in random Boolean networks.
2. The authors describe the phase transition in random Boolean networks in terms of the scaling of the number of relevant elements with system size or as a percolation transition in the set of relevant elements. This approach allows for the direct drawing of consequences about the statistical properties of the attractors. The authors computed the properties of the attractors in the framework of the annealed approximation, but observed that the results of this approximation are reliable only when the system is chaotic enough. They propose a new approximation scheme that works better in the frozen phase and on the critical line.
3. The study of the relevant elements is complementary to the annealed approximation and is important for understanding the most interesting region in parameter space, which reproduces some features of real cells and is the least understood. The authors define the Kauffman model, which consists of a set of elements, each with a binary variable representing its state of activation. Each element is under the control of other elements, and its state is determined by the states of the control genes and a response function. The control elements are chosen with uniform probability, and the response functions are extracted at random. The dynamics of the system obey a deterministic but disordered evolution law.
</summary>

1. Low-luminosity Active Galactic Nuclei (LLAGNs) are thought to have low luminosities due to very low accretion rates onto supermassive black holes, and are predicted to have a "submillimetre bump" in their spectral energy distribution (SED) caused by an advection-dominated accretion flow (ADAF).
2. The ADAF model predicts high brightness temperatures in radio bands, making future very-long-baseline-interferometry (VLBI) instruments promising for imaging accretion discs. However, there is a gap between observations and the ADAF spectrum at low-frequency radio bands, indicating the existence of additional unknown emission.
3. About half of low-luminosity Seyfert galaxies and LINERs, and at least 25% of transition objects, hold a compact radio core. Most of these cores show nearly flat spectra in 0.5-arcsec resolution, indicating jet domination.
4. A high-frequency observation is promising for detecting the inverted spectrum of the ADAF due to less interference from non-thermal jets and larger flux densities predicted at higher frequencies. However, contamination from diffuse dust may be harmful at certain gigahertz when using a poor spatial resolution.

These WDs have helium cores and are the coolest pulsating WDs ever found. The text also discusses the implications of these discoveries for our understanding of the instability strip and the evolution of ELM WDs.
2. The text describes the observations and analysis of the pulsations in J1614, which was found to have a temperature of about 8600 K and a surface gravity of log g = 5.5, corresponding to a mass of 0.19 solar masses. The text also discusses the lack of significant radial velocity variability in J1614, which suggests that it may be in a nearly face-on orbit or have a cool, low-mass white dwarf companion. The text also describes the discovery of multi-periodic variability in J2228 and the update of its atmospheric parameters. The text concludes with a discussion of these discoveries and their implications for the observed DA WD instability strip.

The discovery of an overdensity of stars, known as the Vertical Red Clump (VRC), in the Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) has been interpreted as an intervening population of stars that may represent a dwarf galaxy or tidal debris. However, this interpretation has been challenged on several grounds, including the lack of evidence for a foreground population in the MACHO team's extensive photometric database and the unlikely hypothesis that the VRC is a clump population.
2. The VRC has been identified as a massive foreground population with about 5% of the angular surface density of the LMC itself. If true, this would have profound consequences for the interpretation of galactic microlensing studies, as such debris could be responsible for a sizable fraction of the microlensing signal toward the LMC.
3. The authors argue that the VRC feature observed in the CMDs of the LMC originates in the LMC itself, due to stellar evolution and not an intervening population. They confirm the presence of substructure in LMC red clump morphology corresponding to the VRC and show that the VRC corresponds precisely in magnitude and color to the so-called "blue loops" experienced by aging intermediate-mass core He-burning stars.

1. Heavy fermion systems are characterized by a hierarchy of energy scales, with the Kondo scale marking the screening of local magnetic moments through a many-body effect that entangles the spins of conduction electrons and local moments.
2. Below the coherence temperature, which tracks the Kondo scale, a paramagnetic heavy-fermion liquid emerges, characterized by a large fermi surface with Luttinger volume including both magnetic moments and conduction electrons. The coherence temperature is small, indicating a large effective mass.
3. The competition between Kondo screening, which favors paramagnetic ground states, and the Ruderman-Kittel-Kasuya-Yosida (RKKY) interaction, which favors magnetically ordered states, is at the heart of quantum phase transitions. Two radically different scenarios have been proposed to describe this quantum phase transition.
4. The first scenario, the Herzt-Millis picture, suggests that the quasi-particles of the heavy-fermion liquid remain intact across the transition and undergo a spin-density wave transition. The second scenario links the quantum critical point to the very breakdown of the quasi-particle of the heavy-fermion state and a topological reorganization of the fermi surface across the transition.
5. Recent experiments show that a change in fermi surface topology must not necessarily occur only at the magnetic order-disorder quantum critical point. In fact, even in YBa2Ru3Si2, the fermi surface reconstruction can be shifted to either side of the qcp via application of positive or negative chemical pressure.
6. The authors address these questions through an explicit calculation of the fermi surface topology in the framework of the Kondo lattice model (KLM). They present detailed dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) calculations aimed at the investigation of the KLM ground state and map out the magnetic phase diagram as a function of coupling and conduction electron density.
</summary>

The ratio of total to selective extinction is a commonly used measure of the slope of the extinction/reddening law.
3. Galactic dust displays a wide range of behavior, and significant deviations from the canonical value of the ratio of total to selective extinction are known to exist for a variety of interstellar dust clouds. These variations appear to be generally correlated with environment.
4. Measurements are necessary along many sight lines through a broad range of cloud types to improve our understanding of the dependence of the ratio of total to selective extinction on environment.

1. The interstellar medium (ISM) of a typical disk galaxy is divided into hot ionized gas, warm neutral medium, and cold neutral medium. Star formation is restricted to cold dense gas and is strongly correlated with the molecular gas content. However, the link between star formation and molecular gas is probably not causal, and molecular gas is an indispensable tracer of star forming regions in the local and distant universe.
2. The gas temperature sets the characteristic size and mass of prestellar cores that develop in post-shock regions within magnetized, star-forming clouds. Tracking molecular chemistry is crucial to accurately represent small-scale fragmentation in numerical simulations of star-forming clouds. Young, massive stars are the main source of far-ultraviolet (FUV) photons that permeate the ISM and readily photodissociate interstellar molecules. Molecular gas is found predominantly in dense, cold regions where dust shielding and self-shielding by the molecules themselves have attenuated the interstellar radiation field (ISRF) intensity far below its mean.
3. The transition zones separating atomic and molecular gas, so-called photodissociation regions (PDRs), have been studied extensively both numerically and theoretically. The outer, unshielded layers of a PDR are composed of atomic hydrogen and singly ionized carbon. As column density increases, the atomic-to-molecular transition begins to occur, with the C-CO transition occurring interior to the HI-H2 one. Deeper still, when external FUV photons have been entirely absorbed, the chemistry and thermodynamics become dominated by the presence of deep penetrating cosmic rays and the freeze-out of molecules onto dust grains.
4. Implementing processes such as turbulent motions, thermal processes, supernovae, and stellar winds in a numerical simulation is highly non-trivial. Three-dimensional simulations of finite, but representative, portions of galactic disks have attempted to replicate a supernova-driven ISM, finding success in reproducing a multiphase ISM or demonstrating the regulation of the star formation rate (SFR) by stellar feedback. However, studies that have examined the atomic-to-molecular transition within large-scale, three-dimensional simulations have received far less attention.

1. The fraction of star-forming galaxies decreases as a function of increasing local galaxy density in the low redshift universe, a correlation known as the star formation-density relation. This relation has been confirmed in many studies using optical and UV data to trace star formation in massive galaxy clusters and field environments.
2. Mid-infrared data from ISO and MIPS have revealed the presence of highly obscured, dusty star-forming galaxies that were previously undetected by optical or UV surveys. However, there are still only a small number of low redshift clusters that have been systematically surveyed for dusty star-forming galaxies out to the virial radius.
3. WISE data is being used to study obscured star formation and its relationship to cluster mass and radius out to 3 in a sample of 69 clusters at z ~ 0.05. WISE has completed observations of the entire sky in four infrared bands, providing at least eight exposures per position on the ecliptic and increasing depth towards the ecliptic poles.
4. The photometry used for analyses is point spread function (PSF) fitted magnitudes from the first-pass operations coadd source working database created by the WISE data reduction pipeline. Galaxies in the cluster sample have a diffraction limited resolution of 12" (full width half maximum) in the 22 μm band.
5. To ensure an unbiased comparison of global star formation rates (SFRs) and total infrared luminosities of clusters at different redshifts, a lower limit of SFR=4.6 is imposed on the entire cluster sample, which is equivalent to a total infrared luminosity of 6 x 10^10 L☉, and corresponds to the 6 mJy flux limit at z ~ 0.05.
6. The sample of star-forming galaxies, referred to as demi-LIRGs, have nearly half the total infrared luminosity of a luminous infrared galaxy or LIRG. However, it is noted that most coadded observations will have at least 12 overlapping frames and hence better sensitivity than the conservative 6 mJy limit used in this paper.

</summary>

Research has been conducted to condense two species of atoms simultaneously, partially achieved for two different hyperfine spin states of  ^87Rb, and the dynamics of their complex relative motion have been studied. The possibility of measuring the relative phase between the two condensates has also been demonstrated.
2. Theoretical investigation of two-component Bose systems has been carried out, with recent experiments reviving interest in the theory of such systems. Hartree-Fock theory has been successfully tested on the two-component  ^87Rb system, and the stability, ground-state properties, and collective excitations have been studied using the Gross-Pitaevskii equations. The effects of symmetry and symmetry breaking are also discussed, with the quantum state of the binary Bose system characterized by two phases of the two condensates.

1. Broad emission iron lines are common features in the spectra of active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries, originating near the black hole due to radiation reflection on the accretion disc.
2. The black hole's spin influences the line shape, determining the position of the marginally stable orbit, which confines the inner edge of the accretion disc.
3. The Laor model, which includes the effects of a maximally rotating Kerr black hole, has been widely used to describe relativistic disc spectral lines, but its limitation of a fixed spin value has been relaxed in the Ky models.
4. The Laor model can still be used to estimate the spin if the inner edge of the disc is identified with the marginally stable orbit, with the spin being derived from the lower boundary of the broad line.
5. The comparison of the Laor and Ky models is shown in figure [intro], and other parameters of relativistic line models include inclination angle, rest energy of the line, inner and outer radii of the disc, and emissivity parameters.
6. The emissivity of the line is given by different expressions for different radii, and the angular dependence of the emissivity is characterized by a limb darkening profile in the Laor model.
7. The paper compares the Laor and Ky models applied to current data provided by the XMM-Newton satellite and artificial data generated for the upcoming X-ray mission, focusing on two sources with skewed iron lines.
8. The analysis used the SAS software version 7.1.2, ftools, and xspec for reducing XMM-Newton data and fitting the models to the data.

<summary>

1. The accretion of gas onto a supermassive black hole (SMBH) in the nucleus of galaxies is believed to be the source of activity in quasars and Seyfert galaxies, also known as active galactic nuclei (AGNs). The mass of the SMBH in these objects is correlated with the luminosity, mass, and velocity dispersion of the stellar spheroid of the galaxies. This correlation suggests an evolutionary relation between the growth of the SMBH and the host galaxy.
2. The reverberation mapping technique is an independent method to estimate the mass of the black hole in AGNs. This technique uses the time lag between variations in the continuum emission and the broad emission lines to determine the size of the broad line region (BLR). The mass of the black hole can then be estimated using the velocity dispersion of the broad component of the emission lines and assuming virial equilibrium.
3. The reverberation mapping technique has been used to make estimates of SMBH masses over a large range of redshift. However, the technique is observationally taxing and has only been applied to about three dozen AGNs. A correlation has been found between the BLR size and the optical continuum luminosity at 5100 Å, which can be used to estimate the SMBH masses from single-epoch spectra and calibrate other surrogate relations used for black hole mass estimates.
4. The extrapolation of the known BLR-luminosity relation to low luminosities suggests that the time lag between the variations of the broad line and that of the continuum will be of the order of hours to days for low luminosity sources. Therefore, monitoring programs of short durations, but fast sampling, are required to estimate the reverberation time lags for low luminosity sources.
5. The paper presents the optical spectroscopic and photometric observations of a new low luminosity AGN, the X-ray source and Seyfert 1.5 galaxy H 0507 + 164. Based on a reverberation mapping campaign that lasted for about a month, the authors have obtained the time lag and estimated the mass of the SMBH.

</summary>

1. The Bishop-Phelps theorem states that every bounded linear functional on a Banach space can be approximated by norm attaining functionals, while Lindenstrauss proved that the same result does not hold for bounded linear operators in general.
2. The Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás theorem is a numerical version of the Bishop-Phelps theorem, which states that given a Banach space and a bounded linear functional, there exist a point and a norm attaining functional that satisfy certain conditions.
3. The concept of uniform convexity is defined, and it is shown that a Banach space is uniformly convex if and only if given a subspace and a vector, there exists a positive number such that whenever the norms of the difference between the vector and any other vector in the subspace satisfy a certain relation, there exists a vector in the subspace that is close to the original vector and has a smaller norm.
4. The strong Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property (SBPP) is introduced, which is a stronger version of the Bishop-Phelps-Bollobás property for bounded linear operators. It is shown that a Banach space has the SBPP if and only if given a subspace and a vector, there exists a positive number such that whenever the norms of the difference between the vector and any other vector in the subspace satisfy a certain relation, there exists a vector in the subspace that is close to the original vector and has a smaller norm, and the functional that almost attains its norm at some point is the same as the functional that attains its norm at the new vector.
5. It is shown that if a Banach space is uniformly convex, then it has the SBPP, and a characterization of uniformly convex Banach spaces is given in terms of the SBPP.
6. The SBPP is studied for bounded linear operators, and it is shown that there are uniformly convex Banach spaces and infinite-dimensional Banach spaces such that the pair fails the SBPP.
7. A complete characterization of the SBPP for the pair is given, which describes when these pairs satisfy the property.

</summary>

1. An anomaly in field theory occurs when a symmetry of the classical action or conservation law is violated in the quantized version. This discovery was made by Adler, Bell, and Jackiw, and Bardeen in 1969.
2. External and internal symmetries have different physical implications when broken. The breakdown of an external symmetry provides physical explanations for certain phenomena, while the breakdown of an internal symmetry leads to inconsistencies in the quantum theory.
3. Gravitation, when regarded as a gauge theory, also suffers from anomalies, which can be classified as Einstein, Lorentz, or Weyl anomalies. These anomalies have been calculated using various methods, including perturbation theory, heat kernel method, Fujikawa's path integral approach, and mathematical techniques such as differential geometry, cohomology, and topology.
4. Schwinger terms, which are additional terms in the canonical algebra of equal time commutators, are deeply related to anomalies. They can be calculated using perturbation theory, heat kernel method, and Fujikawa's path integral approach.
5. The work of the authors deals with the calculation of gravitational anomalies, specifically the Einstein anomaly and the Weyl anomaly, using the method of dispersion relations.
6. The method of dispersion relations provides an independent and complementary view of the anomaly phenomenon compared to ultraviolet regularization procedures. It manifests the anomaly as a peculiar infrared feature of the imaginary part of the amplitude.
7. The paper is organized into several sections, discussing the general structure of the amplitude, Ward identities, dispersion relations, the anomalous Ward identities, and the gravitational Schwinger terms.

</summary>

2. The acceleron's potential is modulated by changes in neutrino density, causing the neutrino mass to depend on its number density and change with the evolution of the universe. The equation of state parameter and dark energy density also evolve with the neutrino mass.

2. The "displace, cut and reflect" method is commonly used to generate these solutions. However, one major issue with this method is that the matter content of the disk is usually anisotropic, with the radial pressure being different from the azimuthal pressure. In most solutions, the radial pressure is null, making them unphysical.
3. In this article, the authors apply the "displace, cut and reflect" method to spherically symmetric solutions of Einstein's field equations in isotropic coordinates to generate static disks made of perfect fluid, i.e., with radial pressure equal to tangential pressure. They also consider disks of perfect fluid surrounded by an halo made of perfect fluid matter.

Section II gives an overview of the "displace, cut and reflect" method and presents the basic equations used to calculate the main physical variables of the disks. Section III applies the formalism to obtain the simplest model of disk based on Schwarzschild's vacuum solution in isotropic coordinates.
5. Sections IV and V present some models of disks with halos obtained from different known exact solutions of Einstein's field equations for static spheres of perfect fluid in isotropic coordinates. Section VI discusses the results.

1. The Mott-Hubbard model of interacting bosons on a lattice has been used to describe superfluid-Mott insulator transitions in various systems, including Josephson arrays, granular superconductors, and cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice. The recent experimental observation of this transition in cold atoms has triggered significant theoretical and experimental activity.
2. The essential physics of cold bosonic atoms in an optical lattice is captured by a bosonic Mott-Hubbard model describing the competition between hopping and on-site interaction. Various approximation schemes, such as the Gutzwiller mean-field ansatz, density-matrix renormalization group (DMRG), exact diagonalization (ED), and quantum Monte Carlo (QMC), have been used to study this model.
3. In this article, the authors study short-range correlations, not included by the Gutzwiller ansatz, by using perturbation theory to find corrections to the short-range behavior of the one-particle density matrix, which is directly relevant to experimentally observed expansion patterns.
4. The perturbative approach is identical to previous work in the insulating state, where the goal was to study corrections to the phase diagram. Numerical results are presented and discussed for local observables and the density matrix.
5. Implications for expansion patterns both for bulk systems and a harmonic confining potential are discussed. The cold bosonic gas in the optical lattice can be described by a Mott-Hubbard model, with the Gutzwiller approach providing a good approximation in the limits of deep Mott insulator and superfluid phases.

A recent paper discusses how compactification on a compact hyperbolic manifold with a time-dependent volume modulus results in a flat, expanding universe that undergoes transient acceleration. Subsequent studies have shown that such cosmological solutions are typical in compactifications involving compact hyperbolic spaces or non-vanishing flux.

The transient acceleration in these models can be explained by the positive scalar field potential that both hyperbolic and flux compactifications produce in the effective, lower-dimensional action. The paper also discusses the analysis of a special case where the target space has a one-dimensional factor parametrized by a dilaton field, and the potential takes a specific form for a certain "dilaton coupling" constant.
3. The paper aims to generalize this type of analysis to the multi-scalar case and determine what can be said about cosmologies with more general scalar potentials. The authors develop an alternative method of visualizing cosmological solutions that applies to any potential and illustrate it with an application to exponential potentials.

1. Pulsed high-frequency (HF) electromagnetic (EM) waves are used to sound the density profile and drift velocity of the overhead ionosphere. In 1971, it was theoretically shown that strong enough injected HF radio beams could excite weak-turbulence parametric instabilities in the ionospheric plasma.
2. Ionospheric modification experiments in Platteville, Colorado, and Arecibo, Puerto Rico, demonstrated the heating of electrons, deformation in ionosonde records, excitation of spread F, and the triggering of weak-turbulence parametric instabilities in the ionosphere.
3. Numerical simulations have become an important tool to understand the complex behavior of plasma turbulence. A full-scale simulation study of the propagation of an HF EM wave into the ionosphere was conducted, considering realistic scale sizes of the ionosphere and the wavelength of the EM waves.
4. The simulation results suggest that such simulations will become a powerful tool to study HF-induced ionospheric turbulence and secondary radiation on a quantitative level for direct comparison with experimental data.
5. The propagation of an EM pulse through the neutral atmosphere and ionospheric layer was studied, observing Faraday rotation, the excitation of the R-X and L-O modes, and the conversion of the L-O mode into electrostatic waves.
6. Weakly damped oscillations of the electric field component were interpreted as electrostatic waves produced by mode conversion of the L-O mode. The nonlinear effects at the turning point of the L-O and R-X modes were also investigated, showing large-amplitude pump waves, second harmonics, and low-frequency oscillations.

1. The STE-Quest mission is a medium-sized candidate for launch in 2022/2024 by the European Space Agency (ESA) to test Einstein's Equivalence Principle (EEP) by measuring the gravitational red-shift and testing the universality of free fall.
2. The mission comprises a space segment and a ground segment, connected by highly stable bi-directional microwave and optical links for precise time- and frequency-transfer.
3. The space segment includes a satellite, two instruments (Atomic Clock and Atom Interferometer), science link equipment, and precise orbit determination equipment.
4. The ground segment consists of three ground terminals connected to highly accurate ground-clocks, used to perform various measurement types, including earth gravitational red-shift measurements, sun gravitational red-shift measurements, moon gravitational red-shift measurements, and atom interferometer measurements.
5. The Atomic Clock is a rebuilt of the high-precision PHARAO clock used in the ACES mission, with an optically derived microwave signal for short-term stability.
6. The Atom Interferometer uses interference between matter waves to generate an interference pattern that depends on external forces acting on the atoms under test, with differential measurements performed simultaneously with two isotopes of rubidium atoms to reject unwanted external noise sources.
7. The science links comprise optical and microwave time & frequency links to compare the on-board clock with distributed ground clocks and allow distant ground clocks to be compared to one another using the on-board segment as a relay.
8. The precise orbit determination equipment is required to determine the spacecraft position and velocity, allowing theoretical predictions of the expected gravitational red-shifts and the relativistic doppler to be compared to the measured ones.
9. The baseline orbit is highly elliptical, maximizing gravity gradients between apogee and perigee to achieve mission objective 1 (earth gravitational red-shift), and features a slight drift of the right-ascension of the ascending node due to the non-spherical earth gravitational potential.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The quark-gluon plasma (QGP) is a phase of quantum chromodynamics where quarks and gluons are mostly liberated from hadrons. The phase transition structure of QCD is an active area of research, and the quark matter can be created in heavy ion colliders or in the early universe and super-dense stars. A work generalizes previous calculations for the region with finite temperature and baryon density by considering weakly interacting quarks in the one gluon exchange scheme. The paper calculates the thermodynamic properties of QGP and compares it with strange quark matter.
2. The thermodynamic quantities of QGP are obtained as a function of chemical potential and temperature, and then rewritten as a function of temperature and baryon density. The energy density, entropy, and free energy are evaluated from the partition function. The phase diagram is extracted by solving the equation for the pressure balance between QGP and hadronic pressures. The excluded volume effect for the nuclear matter equation of state is used to calculate the hadronic pressure. The interaction energy between quarks is calculated using the Landau Fermi liquid model.
</summary>

<summary>

1. High-temperature superconductors (HTS) have been found to have mainly d-wave pairing symmetry, with a predominant d-gap symmetry up to the superconducting critical temperature. This symmetry has been confirmed through try-crystal phase-sensitive measurements and thermal transport measurements.
2. The effect of pinning of vortices plays an important role in determining the correct angle pattern in thermal conductivity measurements. A field-cooled procedure must be used to rule out the influence of this effect. The angular patterns of the longitudinal thermal conductivity at different temperatures for twinned and untwinned crystals are shown in figs.[fig2] and [fig3].
3. The variation of the thermal conductivity can be explained with a model involving a Doppler shift in the energy spectrum of the quasiparticles along with an accurate inclusion of the impurity scattering and/or assuming Andreev scattering of quasiparticles by vortices.
4. The symmetry of the curves differs slightly for twinned and untwinned samples at the same absolute or reduced temperature. This can be explained by an impurity-dependent gap parameter or by the ratio of the modulus of the gap and the density of states of the quasiparticles at a temperature t and momentum p.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The term "stochastic resonance" was introduced in the early 1980s in the study of periodic advances of glaciers on Earth. It refers to the effect of nonmonotone dependence of a system's response on noise when noise (e.g., temperature) is added to a periodic input signal.
2. Stochastic resonance is the phenomenon where the transmission of a signal can be improved by the addition of noise. This concept is used in signal estimation, where the goal is to estimate a signal transmitted through a channel that can only reveal signals louder than a threshold.
3. The optimal level of noise, called stochastic resonance, can be determined using statistical criteria such as Shannon mutual information, Kullback divergence, or Fisher information quantity.
4. The paper studies the problem of estimation and hypotheses testing for a model with a threshold, a subthreshold constant and non-negative signal, and a noise that is a trajectory of a diffusion process. Two schemes of observations are proposed: observing the proportion of time spent by the perturbed signal over the threshold and measuring the energy of the perturbed signal when it is above the threshold.
5. The paper proposes two estimators for the schemes and studies their asymptotic properties. It is shown that the estimators are asymptotically equivalent to the maximum likelihood estimators.
6. The paper also studies the problem of testing the simple hypothesis against the simple alternative by applying the Bayesian maximum a posteriori probability criterion. It is noted for the first time that the overall probability of error is nonmonotonic dependent on the noise level.
7. The paper establishes asymptotic properties of estimators given by the generalized method of moments for two models and gives an example of stochastic resonance based on a process where the phenomenon appears pronounced.

</summary>

<summary>

1. Dehn surgery is an operation that modifies a three-manifold by drilling and then regluing a solid torus. The resulting three-manifold via Dehn surgery on a knot in a three-manifold along a slope is denoted by @xmath6. The Cosmetic Surgery Conjecture states that two surgeries on inequivalent slopes are never purely cosmetic.
2. The paper focuses on purely cosmetic surgeries along knots in the three-sphere. The main result is that for most knots in the three-sphere, the resulting three-manifolds are not homeomorphic as oriented manifolds for distinct slopes. A sufficient condition for a knot that admits no purely cosmetic surgery is given in terms of its Jones polynomial.
3. Lescop's surgery formula, which involves a knot invariant satisfying a crossing change formula, is used to prove the main result. This invariant is shown to be the same as the finite type invariant of order two. As an application, the nonexistence of purely cosmetic surgery on certain families of two-bridge knots and Whitehead doubles is proved.
4. The paper also derives an explicit closed formula for the canonically normalized finite type knot invariant of order 3 for two-bridge knots in Conway forms, which could be of independent interest.
5. The paper is organized into sections that review background and properties of the Jones polynomial, define an invariant for rational homology spheres, and study cosmetic surgeries along two-bridge knots and Whitehead doubles in detail.

</summary>

<summary>

1. The convection-diffusion model is a semi-linear parabolic partial differential equation used in various scientific and engineering fields. It can be expressed as an initial value system of partial differential equations with Dirichlet or Neumann boundary conditions.
2. Many numerical methods have been developed to solve the convection-diffusion equation, including finite element method, lattice boltzmann method, finite-difference scheme, and higher-order compact finite difference schemes. A nine-point high-order compact implicit scheme proposed by Noye and Tan is third-order accurate in space and second-order accurate in time, with a large zone of stability.
3. The paper discusses several unconditionally stable finite difference schemes, such as the fourth-order compact finite difference scheme due to Dehghan and Mohebbi, which is unconditionally stable and has the accuracy of order 4. A family of unconditionally stable finite difference schemes presented in has the accuracy of order 4.
4. The paper aims to find the numerical solution of the initial value system of the 3D convection-diffusion equation with both Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions, approximated by the Differential Quadrature Method (DQM) with new sets of modified cubic B-splines as base functions. The resulting system of ODEs is solved by using various time integration algorithms, such as the SSP-RK54 scheme.

</summary>

<summary>

1. A conformally symmetric model for strong interactions at low energies was proposed in ref. [xcite], based on the observation that the dynamical equations of gauge theories retain their flat-space-time form when subject to a conformally-flat metrical field.
2. The model describes confinement of quarks and gluons through the introduction of two scalar fields that spontaneously break the symmetry down to subgroups. A symmetric second-order tensor field is also defined that serves as the metric for flat space-time and couples to electromagnetism.
3. Quarks and gluons are confined to an anti-de-Sitter (AdS) universe with a finite radius in the flat space-time, resulting in flavor-independent oscillations of quarks and gluons inside a closed universe and freely traveling photons through flat space-time.
4. The model comprises one real scalar field and one complex scalar field. The dynamical equations were solved for the case that the respective vacuum expectation values satisfy a certain relation, leading to a solution for AdS confinement via the associated conformally flat metric.
5. Under the condition of the vacuum expectation values relation, one obtains a light scalar field associated with confinement and a very heavy complex scalar field associated with electromagnetism.
6. The model does not easily allow for interactions between hadrons, but it has been further simplified to couple the full AdS spectrum to the channels of two or more hadronic decay products for which scattering amplitudes can be measured.
7. The AdS spectrum reveals itself through the structures observed in hadronic mass distributions, but there is no simple relation between enhancements in experimental cross sections and the AdS spectrum.
8. An AdS oscillation frequency of 38 MeV agrees well with observed results for meson-meson scattering and meson-pair production in the light, heavy-light, and heavy flavor sectors.
9. The coupling of quark-antiquark components to real and virtual two-meson decay channels via quark-pair creation gives a clue about the size of the mass of the scalar field associated with confinement.
10. The possible existence of a quantum with a mass of about 38 MeV, mediating quark-pair creation and having scalar properties, has been proposed as the quantum associated with the above-discussed scalar field for confinement.

<summary>

1. The zero range potential (ZRP) approach, also known as the generalized zero range potential (GZRP), is a theoretical framework used to describe the behavior of particles in scattering problems. It can be represented as a boundary condition on the wavefunction or as a pseudopotential. The Darboux transformation (DT) technique can be used to construct exactly solvable potentials and modify the GZRP boundary condition, creating a potential with arbitrarily disposed discrete spectrum levels for any angular momentum.
2. The DT technique can also be used to dress the ZRP model, which involves modifying the boundary condition on the wavefunction at the origin. This can introduce short-range core interactions in the potential, which depend on the angular momentum of the particle. In the generalized case, the ZRP with angular momentum can also generate complex poles of the S-matrix, which correspond to quasi-stationary states (resonances).
3. The DT can be used to add or remove poles of the S-matrix for the dressed GZRP, allowing for the construction of a zero-range potential eigenfunction in the multi-center problem. This can be useful for describing the behavior of particles in complex systems with multiple scattering centers.
4. The ZRP model has been used to study the scattering of particles by structures with various symmetries, such as domes, regular trihedrons, and regular tetrahedrons. The phases and partial and integral cross sections can be expressed in terms of the symmetry group representation and the distance between the scattering centers. The ZRP model can also be used to study slow electron scattering by polyatomic molecules, and the effects of higher partial waves can be taken into account to improve the agreement between the calculated and experimental cross sections at higher collision energies.

</summary>

<summary>

1. Anomaly-Mediated Supersymmetry Breaking (AMSB) models have attracted attention due to their attractive properties, such as calculable soft supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking terms and real, flavor-invariant terms that solve SUSY flavor problems. However, AMSB models have a well-known problem of negative slepton mass-squared parameters, which can be solved by adding a universal scalar mass to the AMSB Soft SUSY Breaking (SSB) terms.
2. Hypercharged Anomaly Mediation (HCAMSB) is a string-motivated scenario that uses a similar setup as AMSB, with SUSY breaking localized at the bottom of a strongly warped hidden region, geometrically separated from the visible region where the MSSM resides. The warping suppresses contributions due to tree-level gravity mediation, and anomaly mediation can become the dominant source of SUSY breaking in the visible sector.
3. In the MSSM, the bino gaugino mass can be the only soft SUSY breaking parameter not determined by anomaly mediation, and its size can lead to a small perturbation to the spectrum of anomaly mediation or dominate the contribution from anomaly mediation. In extensions of the MSSM, additional fields can also communicate SUSY breaking to the MSSM sector.
4. The minimal AMSB model predicts a negative mass squared for the sleptons, while the pure hypercharge mediation suffers from negative squared masses for stops and sbottoms. The combination of hypercharge and anomaly mediation leads to phenomenologically viable spectra for a sizable range of relative contributions.
5. The hcamsb ssb contribution is parametrized using a dimensionless quantity @xmath2, and the parameter space of hcamsb models is given by @xmath18, @xmath3, @xmath4, and sign (@xmath5). The ssb terms and superpotential term are given by the scalar potential minimization conditions, and the weak scale sparticle mass spectrum is determined by renormalization group evolution.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The introduction of efficient multi-object spectrographs on 4m-class telescopes has enabled the construction of large samples of faint galaxies with measured redshifts, allowing for the direct observation of the evolution of the galaxy population.
2. Several deep, faint galaxy redshift surveys have been conducted, with most findings indicating that the population of blue, star-forming galaxies has evolved strongly since z=1, while the population of red galaxies shows at most modest signs of evolution. However, there are inconsistencies in the luminosity functions (LFs) derived by different groups, which may be due to small sample sizes, small survey areas, and systematic errors.
3. The local LF, essential for estimating quantitative evolution, remains uncertain, with differences in shape, normalization, characteristic luminosity, and faint-end slope among surveys like the Stromlo/APM, CFA, and Las Campanas Redshift Surveys. The largest local survey, the Las Campanas Redshift Survey (LCRS), has a low normalization and a flat faint-end slope, but other surveys have higher normalizations.
4. The Norris Survey of the Corona Borealis Supercluster, aimed at studying supercluster dynamics, also provides a sample for studying the evolution of the LF. The survey's 1654 redshifts, including 1022 galaxies beyond the supercluster, show that the LF varies from the field to the supercluster environment.
5. The paper uses the step-wise maximum likelihood method to estimate the LF and renormalizes weights to account for density fluctuations, resulting in a good agreement between the LCRS and the survey's local LF.

</summary>

<summary>

1. Surveys using bolometer arrays at millimeter and submillimeter wavelengths have discovered dusty objects at extreme redshifts, which are missed in surveys at shorter and longer wavelengths due to obscuration and unfavorable @xmath11 corrections. The discovery of "scuba galaxies" in the late 1990s significantly changed the understanding of galaxy formation and evolution.
2. Radio imaging of submillimeter survey fields has been crucial in detecting and studying these submillimeter galaxies (SMGs). Early radio follow-up detected roughly half of the submm sources observed, with an astrometric precision of @xmath30.3@xmath12, and provided a rough estimate of redshift when combined with submm flux density. Radio data also enabled refinement of submm samples, increasing the detection fraction to two-thirds of SMGs at 0.85-mm flux density levels in excess of @xmath35mjy.
3. Bright SMGs have been found to be a diverse population, including quasar-like galaxies, morphologically complex galaxies, extremely red galaxies, and galaxies with obscured active nuclei and/or superwinds. Spectroscopic redshifts have been difficult to determine, but accurate redshifts reported by Chapman et al. (2003, 2005) facilitated the first systematic measurements of molecular gas mass for SMGs and constraints on gas reservoir size and dynamical mass.
4. A detailed understanding of SMGs remains elusive, with confusion limiting investigations to the brightest SMGs and selection biases potentially skewing the understanding of the population. A robust sample of bright SMGs selected using SCUBA and MAMBO in the Lockman Hole has been presented to determine the true fraction of radio drop-outs and practical information such as the intrinsic positional uncertainty for SMGs in the absence of radio/IR counterparts.

1. The axial anomaly, a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, has been analyzed using the renormalization procedure and the path integral formalism. An alternative approach by Dolgov and Zakharov interprets the anomaly as an infrared phenomenon, arising from a singularity in the chiral limit of the triangular diagram's absorptive part. This infrared interpretation complements the more familiar ultraviolet interpretation from the renormalization procedure.
2. The Dolgov and Zakharov approach has been related to specific effects in the dynamics of physical reactions, such as polarized radiative decays of particles. The authors calculate decay rates for these processes, examining mass singularities and their cancellation, and discuss the kinoshita-lee-nauenberg (KLN) theorem's analogies and differences with unpolarized decay rates. The paper is organized to cover the dispersive approach to the axial anomaly, its physical origin, the extension to the radiative pion decay, and the behavior of the inner bremsstrahlung contribution in the collinear and infrared limits.

1. The invention is related to nerve regeneration, specifically to nerve conduits for peripheral nerve regeneration.
2. Current treatments for peripheral nerve injuries include end-to-end suturing and autograft or allograft biological tissue, but both have limitations.
3. Tissue engineering and biomaterials suggest that biomaterial nerve guidance conduits (NGCs) may overcome these limitations.
4. FDA-approved tissue engineered nerve devices have limitations, including inadequate physical topography and chemical cues, and limited nerve gap repair capability.

<summary>

1. The paper extends the results of Yetter to a deformation theory for arbitrary pasting diagrams of $xmath0$-linear categories, functors, and natural transformations. It establishes that obstructions are cocycles for deformation complexes of pasting diagrams in general, and considers deformations of pasting diagrams with specified functors or natural transformations required to be deformed trivially. The paper also addresses the dependence of cochain maps on choices of association for 2-dimensional compositions in pasting diagrams.
2. The paper uses the cochain maps of previous sections to give explicit examples of deformation complexes associated with various shapes of commutative pasting diagrams. It shows that cochain maps induced by two different associations of the 2-dimensional composition are not equal but chain homotopic, and that only in the context of commutative pasting diagrams is the effect of compositions of 2-arrows evident.
3. The paper introduces a "commutative pillow with triangular cross-section" as the simplest example of a pasting diagram and gives its deformation complex. It also discusses pasting diagrams with 2-dimensional compositions, such as "pillows with square cross-sections," and their deformation complexes. The paper shows that the choice of left-associating or right-associating compositions in these examples leads to different chain maps, but they are homotopic in the homotopy category or derived category.

<summary>

1. Rapidity gaps, regions without hadronic activity in collisions, have been observed at HERA and Fermilab Tevatron, attributed to color singlet quanta exchange between partons.
2. At the Tevatron, a fraction of dijet events exhibit rapidity gaps between jets, indicating color singlet exchange effects relevant at high momentum transfers, raising hopes for quantitative descriptions using perturbative methods.
3. Bjorken predicted a gap fraction of order one percent, with a survival probability of rapidity gaps of around 10%, and a color-singlet fraction in elastic scattering estimated using the imaginary part of the two-gluon color-singlet exchange amplitude.
4. The two-gluon exchange model, with the two-gluon exchange amplitude replaced by its imaginary part, is used to calculate the color singlet fraction, which grows with the color charge of the scattered partons.
5. Measurements by CDF and D0 collaborations show no decrease in the gap fraction with increasing jet transverse momentum or pseudorapidity separation, contrary to the two-gluon exchange model's expectations.
6. The unitarized RPWE framework can accommodate both the increase and decrease of the gap fraction with regularization parameters, encompassing various scenarios.
7. The unitarized gluon exchange model can describe the trend of color singlet fractions growing with transverse momentum, even though it is an extension of the two-gluon exchange model.
8. The variation of RPWE predictions with model parameters highlights the limitations of a perturbative approach to the color singlet exchange probability, while the unitarized two-gluon exchange model can fit present Tevatron data with the phase and survival probability as free parameters.

</summary>

The anvil assembly includes an anvil shaft with a proximal portion having flexible legs that define a first longitudinal bore, and a distal portion with an anvil head assembly that supports an anvil plate with staple deforming pockets. A stabilizing collet, which can be cylindrical and substantially rigid, is positioned within the first longitudinal bore to prevent damage to the flexible legs while coupling the anvil assembly to the stapling device.

The collet has a distal end with cantilevered fingers, each having a protrusion that secures the collet within the first longitudinal bore of the anvil shaft by engaging with holes in the anvil shaft adjacent to the longitudinal channels defined by the flexible legs. The anvil shaft and anvil head assembly are designed to ensure atraumatic entry into and through a body orifice or lumen.
3. The stapling device includes a handle assembly, a body portion, a shell assembly with a staple cartridge, and a trocar that extends from the shell assembly. The anvil assembly and stapling device are coupled together by inserting the trocar into the anvil shaft, which causes the flexible legs to flex outwardly and engage the trocar. The stabilizing collet is positioned to support the flexible legs and minimize the likelihood of damage during engagement with a grasper.

This capability has various applications, including object recognition, image and video compression, video summarization, media re-targeting and photo collage, image quality assessment, image segmentation, content-based image retrieval and image collection browsing, image editing and manipulating, visual tracking, object discovery, and human-robot interaction.

The text also mentions related topics to visual saliency modeling and salient object detection, including object importance, object proposal generation, memorability, scene clutter, image interestingness, video interestingness, surprise, image quality assessment, scene typicality, aesthetic, and attributes.

The text refers to the earliest models that generated interest in image saliency in computer vision and neuroscience communities, including the model proposed by Itti et al. in 1998, which was an implementation of earlier general computational frameworks and psychological theories of bottom-up attention based on center-surround mechanisms.

8. The second wave of interest appeared with works of Liu et al. and Achanta et al., who treated saliency detection as a binary segmentation problem with 1 for a foreground pixel and 0 for a pixel of the background region.
